Entries.default: The beast's blazing eyes glare down at you. Her spiritual presence beats upon your face like the heat from an open blast furnace.
<ispeech>You came, courting oblivion. Remarkable.</ispeech>
<ispeech>Shrouded yourself in the souls of the dead, have you? I sense them clinging to you like snails to a stone.</ispeech>
<ispeech>You've supped from the ruined realms that echo in this empty place. Glutted yourself upon their entropy, as I did once.</ispeech>
<ispeech>And without any effort made to protect yourself from this place. From me. Almost unbelievable. Almost.</ispeech>
<ispeech>It matters not. Nothing matters. I shall claim your essence and use it to escape this place.</ispeech>
"Why are you doing this?"
"Let go. Take your respite in the Void."
"Your relic - it's a phylactery, right? It's sustaining you here."
"Have you considered taking the fight to Rymrgand?"
"You again claim to be trapped here, but I fought you at Harbingers' Watch."
"I'm hunting a god. You think I'd let a dragon stand in my way?"
<ispeech>Why wouldn't I? Would you not, were you trapped here?</ispeech>
<ispeech>Would you not strive to escape this monotonous void?</ispeech>
<ispeech>You witnessed the pull of this place. I cannot escape its gravity. </ispeech>
<ispeech>Not without more essence.</ispeech>
<ispeech>I've taken what I dare from the echoes. Despite their resilience, they remain victims of this place.</ispeech>

<ispeech>The souls you wear put the lie to your words!</ispeech> 

She rears back and bellows.
The dragon exhales slowly through her nostrils, deflating as she does. She lifts her head upwards, as if she might peer out of the Beyond.

<ispeech>Is that why those others cling to you? Your benevolence?</ispeech>

The dragon's head cranes to the side as she peers down at you.

<ispeech>No, little kith. You will indeed aid me, but not in the way you suggest.</ispeech>

The creature's wings flex, the brittle bones and dry flesh cracking in the cold air as it advances.
<ispeech>I've no more time to waste on you. A god requires slaying.</ispeech>
<ispeech>Yours is the mewling of a cub. Let's not prolong this further.</ispeech>
<ispeech>I came here for it. An object of such potency that it defies the deified.</ispeech>
"How do you propose to take my essence?"
"'Nothing matters?' It sounds like this place has made you a part of it."
[Attack] "Let's get this over with."
The creature's laughter echoes in your mind.
<ispeech>It seems the little kith is not quite the fool that it appears.</ispeech>
<ispeech>Such cleverness, little kith.</ispeech>
It matters not what you do. My actions merit greater significance.
<ispeech>In the eldest manner. Via consumption.</ispeech>
<ispeech>The relic shall contain your spirit, shielding it against the White Void.</ispeech>
<ispeech>You shall survive. After a fashion.</ispeech>
"Which relic would that be?"
She waves a claw towards the object floating above the pedestal between you and the dragon. Palpable energy pulses from it.
<ispeech>The anchor. It persists here, when all other things decay to dust.</ispeech>
"What - what is that thing?"
"I sense dozens - perhaps hundreds - of minds contained within that."
"Got meself a bad feeling 'bout that bob, cap. Feels all filled up with souls and hungering for more."
<ispeech>My own protection. They destroy that which threatens their dominion, as they did those who came before me.</ispeech>
"You sought a power to rival the gods? Why?"
"Deified? Not deific? You know then the truth of the gods creation?"
<ispeech>As they would have you, had you not cast yourself into this void.</ispeech>
<ispeech>Obviously. My mother was older than your manufactured gods are now when she hatched me.</ispeech>
<ispeech>Think you our kind oblivious to the workings of kith?</ispeech>
"Who did you mean by 'those who came before you?'"
<ispeech>My elders. When I was yet young, three dragons of inimitable prowess ruled these seas.</ispeech>
<ispeech>So impressive were they that the gods enlisted them in defending their great working.</ispeech>
<ispeech>The elders accepted, and then they vanished. The gods had betrayed them. Entrapped them. Murdered them.</ispeech>
"The oldest Huana legends speak of three guardians, but..." Tekēhu pinches his hair in thought.
The great reptile's head cants to one side as she eyes you.
<ispeech>Aren't we well-studied, little kith?</ispeech>
<ispeech>What of it? Plotting some bit of cleverness?</ispeech>
"Careful, Watcher. She's starting to think you dangerous."
"Let me by, and I'll carry the relic from this place. You'll be free."
"So I don't need to destroy you... I only have to destroy it."
"Can you teach me to fashion my own?"
The dragon's gaze shifts briefly to Ydwin and back to you again. Violet light flickers within its nostrils.
A quiet chuckle rumbles within the beast's long throat.
"Just a scholar's idle curiosity."
<ispeech>Then let us hope it sated.</ispeech>
<ispeech>I could teach you much, were I so inclined. I am afraid, however, that we will not be afforded the opportunity.</ispeech>
<ispeech>You think you would succeed where the god of decay and endings has failed?</ispeech>
<ispeech>No. It shall persist forever, and I with it.</ispeech>
<ispeech>Still, no advantage in leaving such things to chance...</ispeech>
A quiet chuckle rumbles within the beast's long throat.
<ispeech>To what end, little kith? Why would I do such a thing? For that matter, why would you?</ispeech>
"You want to be free of this place, don't you? I'm a Watcher. Helping lost souls is what I do."
"I have my own quarrels with the gods. You'd be a welcome ally."
"I had hoped to learn what you have to teach."
"I mean, it's either that or I kill you."
"On second thought, maybe that wasn't such a great suggestion."
"Better you realize it now than later, I suppose." He sighs and pinches the bridge of his nose.
The beast stares down at you. She does not appear amused.
<ispeech>How very ambitious of you.</ispeech>
<ispeech>I could teach you much, were I so inclined. I am afraid, however, that we will not be afforded the opportunity.</ispeech>
"We could have the opportunity. We could have forever."
She cranes her neck, lowering her head towards you. Her breath reeks of rotten meat and mildewed tomes.
Silence hangs on the air as the dragon considers your proposal.
The dragon snorts, puffs of violet flame flickering about her nostrils.
<ispeech>No. I think not.</ispeech>
<ispeech>As pleasant as this diversion has been, the time comes to conclude our conversation. Farewell, little kith, and welcome to oblivion.</ispeech>
The dragon snorts, puffs of violet flame flickering about her nostrils.
<ispeech>You? You who so clearly wear your devotion to your deity upon your spirit?</ispeech>
<ispeech>You do, don't you? What plans have you for us, our alliance of two?</ispeech>
"I once served Berath willingly. They lost my devotion when they held my life hostage."
"Eothas killed me, destroyed my home, and consumed the souls of those I held dear. I will never forgive him."
"Deity. Singular. The rest get no devotion from me."
"We start by killing Eothas. And this time we make sure he stays dead."
"We make sure everyone knows the truth about the gods."
"We gather power and knowledge until we can challenge them on their own level."
<ispeech>In taking corporeal form, he has made himself vulnerable...</ispeech>
"Hey, now. I'm on board for stopping Eothas, but if you're really planning to kill him, we're gonna need to talk things over."
"Did I hear you right, Watcher? Gaun's the reaper, not the reaped."
<ispeech>I am amused. And intrigued. I do not remember when I was last either of those things.</ispeech>
<ispeech>You have convinced me. Take the relic. Let the pair of us shake Hel itself.</ispeech>

<ispeech>An interesting proposal. And very ambitious.</ispeech>

The dragon lapses into silence, apparently considering your words.

<ispeech>How... uninspired. And disappointingly naïve. The kith will believe what they choose, not what is true.</ispeech>

The dragon roughly shakes her massive head.
"Pardon? Surely I must have misheard you."
"Is this truly our purpose, captain? I am feeling oddly... misled." Tekēhu furrows his brow and studies you.
"Magran's the goddess of fire. I think she'll appreciate watching the other gods burn."
"You think Skaen doesn't want to see the gods torn down? He hates them."
"Pretend you to know what Wael desires?"
<ispeech>Ah. That explains the mark upon your soul. I had thought it willingly accepted. Interesting.</ispeech>
Silence hangs on the air as the dragon considers your proposal.

<ispeech>Nor should you forgive such betrayal.</ispeech>

The dragon examines you, craning her neck to do so.
"Well Hel, Watcher. It ain't his fault you built a house on top his head. You can't hardly expect the sun not to rise, can you?"
"Is that all it takes to get on your bad side?"
"Nor should you be expected to."
<ispeech>What tactic would you have our alliance of two employ against gods?</ispeech>
"I try to help where I can."
"I'm not beneficent. I just fix what's broken."
"I'd get lonely without my phantasmal friends."
"I've made my offer. Take it or leave it."
<ispeech>I have known a few Watchers in my centuries, each unique, the only commonality their mad insight.</ispeech>
<ispeech>I remain unconvinced.</ispeech>

<ispeech>And you would add me to your menagerie.</ispeech>

The great beast harrumphes, violet light spilling from her cracked mouth.
The beast's mouth curls at the edges, revealing rotten teeth - each longer than a stiletto. Her laughter rings in your mind.
<ispeech>You would fix me, then?</ispeech>
<ispeech>You amuse me, little kith. You have no idea how long it has been since I last laughed.</ispeech>
<ispeech>I smell it on you. The cloying scent of compassion.</ispeech>
"I would free you of this prison."
"Rymrgand doesn't want you here, and you don't want to be here. It seems some fixing is in order."
"Maybe 'fix' was the wrong word."
"These spirits are just the beginning. You should see my crew."
"I'd help you, if I you'd let me."
"I've already got a pet dragon. I'm looking for an ally."
<ispeech>This situation satisfies no one, does it?</ispeech>
<ispeech>Very well. You may take the relic.</ispeech>
<ispeech>I shall watch. And I shall listen.</ispeech>
<ispeech>Give me no reason to reclaim it.</ispeech>
"Let's be off before it changes its mind."
"Well done, captain! And here with me thinking you were just another pretty face."
"Most impressive. I thought a violent confrontation a near certainty. Happily, I am proved wrong."
"You never seek the more straightforward solutions to your dragon problems, do you? Ekera, I respect this."

"I saw that, Ishi. Drop it. Now." 

Maia points at the ground until Ishiza reluctantly opens his talons and lets the relic fall back to where he found it.
"Good. I was not looking forward to fighting this creature. Now let us go."
"I admit I'm impressed. So, uh, are we finished in this place? Can we leave?"
"Do you know how long you've been down here?"
The beast's nostrils flare as she arches her back, her wings flexing and twitching towards the tips.
<ispeech>Years. Decades. It matters not.</ispeech>
"Try centuries."
"I think it's been a while."

<ispeech>So I had noticed.</ispeech>

Her hind claws gouge furrows in the rime-crusted ground.

<ispeech>Centuries...</ispeech>

The dragon drops to all four paws, her head bowing slightly.
<ispeech>I expected a century, but not multiple.</ispeech>
"You sound tired."
"I'm sorry I brought it up."
"You should probably just give up."
"For frost's sake! Could you not at least attempt to sound convincing?!"
<ispeech>I disagree.</ispeech>
<ispeech>You sound small. And edible.</ispeech>
<ispeech>What's done is done.</ispeech>

<ispeech>Do battle with the Beast of Winter? To what conceivable end?</ispeech>

She leers at you.
"If you're so great and powerful, killing a little old god shouldn't be too tough."
"To be free of this place? To consume his essence? Perhaps to become a god yourself?"
"It'd be better than waiting around here, wouldn't it?"
Her head swings down, a single blazing eye casting its light across your features.
<ispeech>Do you mock me, little kith?</ispeech>
"Only a little."
"Not at all. You've been in Rymrgand's home for all of this time, and he hasn't been able to kill you yet, has he?"
"Are you mad?!"

"Well then. I hope your amusement was worth it, Watcher."

Ydwin's hand strays to her weapon.
"Merla."

"You know, you might have gotten me into position first." 

Maia shakes her head and slowly reaches for a gun.

"Aw, for fuck's sake, cap."

Serafen reaches for a weapon.
Mirke giggles wordlessly, then hiccups.
Her enraged roar reverberates within your ribs.

<ispeech>It does not follow that he fears me. Still... it is curious...</ispeech>

Her head rises, canting slightly as she considers your words.
"It is like I am not even here."
"I'm happy to help, if you need the assistance."
"Everything ends. Rymrgand included."

<ispeech>Do not think that I don't recognize what you intend with your words, little one.</ispeech>

She growls, long and low.
"If kith created the gods, it stands to reason that they can be destroyed."
<ispeech>You would have me eat Rymrgand? To pluck him from the Void as I might a heifer from a field?</ispeech>

The dragon snorts, purple light flickering within her nostrils. 

You're not sure whether or not she was amused.
<ispeech>That a thing is possible does not render it trivially easy.</ispeech>

<ispeech>Still... if I am to move against him, it needs be now, at the height of my prowess.</ispeech>

The dragon raises her head, straightening.
"Why not? He's nothing but essence, right?"
"He is an aurochs."
<ispeech>That a thing is possible does not render it trivially easy.</ispeech>
"Di verus."
"I'm not sure what else I can say. Maybe you win, maybe you don't. But at least you tried."

<ispeech>And yet...</ispeech>

Her head bobs, eyes dimming slightly in thought.
"It won't be easy, but you can theoretically syphon the god's essence, dividing it between yourself and your relic. What you can't contain between the two, you can destroy."
"It's not... impossible." Aloth chews a knuckle as he thinks.
"Now I didn't follow all of that, but if Rymrgand ain't broken you down yet, maybe he can't."
<ispeech>Yes, I've heard your words, little kith.</ispeech>
"The fact that Rymrgand has not yet managed to defeat the dragon nor destroy its phylactery suggests it may be able to contain the god's power."
<ispeech>Even you must understand that inaction is sometimes the wisest action.</ispeech>
<ispeech>Even you must understand that inaction is sometimes the wisest action.</ispeech>
"You can't just sit around here doing nothing!"
"I didn't take you for a whimpering coward."
[Shrug] "Suit yourself."
"Not everyone lives at the same pace. You never think of those quiet years at Caed Nua and wish you could have it all back?"
<ispeech>You will not goad me into throwing away my existence.</ispeech>
A low, long growl issues from the dragon.
"Why haven't you given up?"
Her head twists fluidly, angling first one eye down upon you, then the other. With a prolonged grinding crunch, her left rear claw digs into the ice.
<ispeech>You ask why I do not allow myself to die? Are you so eager to meet your own end, knowing that nothing awaits beyond?</ispeech>
<ispeech>I will happily introduce you, if you so desire.</ispeech>
"We don't desire. Not even a little."
"Look at yourself. You're already dead."
"Point taken."
The dragon glowers down at you, claws slowly retracting from the ice as she relaxes.
<ispeech>No,</ispeech> she hisses.
<ispeech>So long as will persists, so too does life!</ispeech>
"This isn't life! You're desperately clinging to an eternity of endless, futile struggle."
The dragon's head whips back, recoiling as if struck, and she bellows, her roar shaking the air within your lungs.
"I'm sorry. That was uncalled for. I don't have any answers for you."
[Specified 0] glances at you askance.
She drops her snout again, mouth curling back over browning fangs. Her growl vibrates your bones.
<ispeech>Tell me then, little kith, what you would have me do. What would your wisdom demand of me?</ispeech>

<ispeech>Then you have no purpose!</ispeech>

The dragon roars again.

"Oh gods oh gods oh gods."

The ice crunches beneath his tread as the godlike stumbles backwards.
"It's always the glowing ones that cause the trouble, ain't it?"
She glares at you, her eyes a pair of smoldering coals. You feel her arcane senses rove over you, laying you bare to her.
<ispeech>You said it has been centuries. I tell you, it has felt like so much longer.</ispeech>
"Rest then. You've earned it."
<ispeech>I like him more than I like you, little kith.</ispeech>
<ispeech>I died the moment I passed into the Beyond. Everything since has been... futile.</ispeech>
"That's fair."
"You just don't know him that well."
[Say nothing.]
Vatnir sighs and shakes his head.
<ispeech>I am so... very, very tired.</ispeech>
"A tragic, if accurate, assessment. I cannot help but wonder if there was something more we could have done."
"Somehow this ending don't feel all that happy."
"I... yes. Well done. Let us continue."
"What we have here is a creature that ought to learn to forgive itself. Get that sorted out and you can move on with a clear conscience."
"I think I had this nightmare once."
"Are we dead as well, then? By your logic? ...Let's go."
<ispeech>And what would you do with forever?</ispeech>
"Explore everywhere. Learn everything."
"What wouldn't I do? Forever's a long time to experience a lot of things. And people. And positions."
"Serve you faithfully."
"Whatever I damn well please, skull-face."
"I don't know, but I'll have plenty of time to figure it out."
The dragon snorts, then shakes her head roughly.  It almost gives the impression that she's chuckling.
The dragon's tail curls, then lashes the ground behind her.
The dragon snorts, then shakes her head roughly.  It almost gives the impression that she's chuckling.
The dragon snorts, then shakes her head roughly.  It almost gives the impression that she's chuckling.
The dragon snorts, then shakes her head roughly.  It almost gives the impression that she's chuckling.
<ispeech>An unexpectedly wise answer, little kith.</ispeech>

"Well... I- I suppose there would be much to learn."

Aloth looks quickly away. A crimson blush colors the tips of his ears.

"Don't mind me, captain. I'm just curious to see where you go with this." 

Maia brushes off her palms and takes a step back to observe.
"Captain, you might have spoken to me first. I am not beyond considering the possibilities." Tekēhu squints up at the dragon.

"Well, Hel, Watcher. Let's all just pretend like I ain't here." 

Hands on her hips, Xoti exhales, sending aloft an errant strand of hair.
<ispeech>Disappointing, but not unexpected.</ispeech>
Silence hangs on the air as the dragon considers your proposal.
<ispeech>You're rather more intriguing than I expected, little magician.</ispeech>
<ispeech>You clearly possess some cleverness, little kith. But are you clever enough?</ispeech>
<ispeech>Very well. You may take the relic.</ispeech>
<ispeech>I shall watch. And I shall listen.</ispeech>
<ispeech>And perhaps you will eventually prove your worth.</ispeech>
<ispeech>One would think you rather more eager for death than eternal life.</ispeech>
"Ekera, it is nothing."
"I want to talk about something else."
The great reptile's head cants to one side as she eyes you.
